What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed an ability to read lots of Latin quickly and address the social/political/literary themes of the Aeneid. I also developed an ability to appreciate the more intricate stylistic details of the text through close reading, particularly for the final paper and presentation assignment.
I learned a more in-depth understanding of the Aeneid and a little bit about all of the twelve books.
The class helped me prepare for the departmental classics comprehensive exam. I was also made more aware of cultural parallels in crafting national identity with mythology.
Close reading, fluency in Latin, understanding of Augustan age
I learned not only how to read latin better but how to exact information in order to analyze it and create a better analysis.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class offers a great overview of the Aeneid, situating the poem in its historical and political context and drawing out the finer points its literary style. I really appreciated the secondary scholarship articles, which exemplified the process of undertaking a very thorough and refined analysis of the text.  The pace was brisk but manageable, and the extra section meeting was very helpful for catching up on the Latin we didn't get to in class or continuing a discussion about one of the more complicated passages.

I wish there was more time for discussion in both lecture and discussion section - the five quizzes ended up consuming many days of discussion on books of the Aeneid, which was unfortunate, and class time was often spent dwelling on minute translation problems or having the professor do most of the speaking on the text. The course also would have benefitted if there were another dedicated bridge Latin class this semester because the level of understanding of Latin grammar could differ sometimes greatly between students. The course could also have gone at a faster pace (reading more lines per class) especially by the end of the semester.
I wish we spent more time discussing the passages rather than translating them in class.
Amazing course! Not much to say in recommendation except maybe talking a bit more about the secondary sources in section

Strengths: lots of communication, the insight Professor Freudenberg gives is incredible, I felt much better about analyzing Latin by the end
Weakness: most of the class is spent translating which wasn't my favorite but pretty common in latin

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All COVID-19 practices were helpful. The virtual format of our seminar/discussion meetings worked well and both the professor and the TA were always willing to meet in Zoom office hours.

They were fine. Maybe breakout rooms would have been nice for in class discussion a few times? A dedicated live office hour with the professor and teaching fellow once a week would have been nice to - sometimes it's nice to pop in to ask an instructor a quick question in person (or via zoom) than emailing, especially in such an isolating semester.
I think the sections were incredible. I felt always engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definitely! It's a great way to improve your Latin fluency and dive deeper into one of the most influential works of the Roman world.
Yes, it's an superb course on the Aeneid and covers so much!
If you enjoy epic (or plan on taking the comprehensive exam), this is a must.

I think this course is a wonderful choice if you want to learn more about the Latin language and continue taking Latin in college. However, if youre a rising first-year, I would make sure that you feel confident in your grammar/vocabulary skills before taking this class. It was pretty intimidating taking the class alongside grad students, DS people, etc.

If you like Vergil or just like Latin in general, this is an amazing course! Professor Freudenburg teaches with such passion and obvious love of the text, and the Aeneid always has more to give even to the most seasoned readers. Strongly recommend anyone with some experience in translating Latin poetry to try it out when it's next offered
Yes! The class was fascinating. Even if you have looked at the Aeneid before, this will make you rethink all you know. It is truly an incredible class.

comments: Some pre-recorded lectures were also available at the start of the semester
a once weekly discussion section also happened.
